intro: Uragoga interrupta, commonly known as the interrupted uragoga, is a flowering plant native to specific regions in South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its palmate leaves and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that bloom in shades of pink and white. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetland or riparian habitats. Due to its unique morphology and ecological role, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
